sn35.234:4.1: At one time Venerables Ānanda and Udāyī were staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
sn35.234:4.2: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Udāyī came out of solitude, went to Venerable Ānanda,
sn35.234:4.4: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
sn35.234:5.1: “Reverend Ānanda, the Buddha has explained, opened, and illuminated in many ways how this body is not-self.
sn35.234:5.2: Is it possible to explain consciousness in the same way? To teach, advocate, establish, open, analyze, and make it clear how consciousness is not-self?”
sn35.234:7.1: Does eye consciousness arise dependent on the eye and sights?”
sn35.234:7.3: “If the cause and condition that gives rise to eye consciousness were to totally and utterly cease without anything left over,
sn35.234:7.4: would eye consciousness still be found?”
sn35.234:7.6: “In this way, too, it can be understood how consciousness is not-self.

sn35.234:10.1: Suppose there was a person who needed heartwood. Wandering in search of heartwood, they’d take a sharp axe and enter a forest.
sn35.234:10.2: There they’d see a big banana tree, straight and young and flawlessly grown.
sn35.234:10.3: He’d cut it down at the base,
sn35.234:10.5: cut off the top, and unroll the coiled sheaths.
sn35.234:10.6: But they wouldn’t even find sapwood, much less heartwood.
sn35.234:10.7: In the same way, a mendicant sees these six fields of contact as neither self nor belonging to self.
sn35.234:10.8: So seeing, they don’t grasp anything in the world.
sn35.234:10.10: Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.
sn35.234:10.11: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
